item.description: [...] this should instantly be a cause for concern to palaeontologists, and relates back to the question of rigorously defining species in the fossil record. Either way, it’s a pretty small sample size, [...]
item.content:encoded: […] this should instantly be a cause for concern to palaeontologists, and relates back to the question of rigorously defining species in the fossil record. Either way, it’s a pretty small sample size, […]

item.title: By: Jaime A. Headden
item.dc:creator: Jaime A. Headden
item.description:
Maxwell (2012) uses morphometric (although not geometric) analyses to quantify variation among a variety of elements (skull, vertebrae, appendicular elements) in a broad selection of specimens from the Posidonia Shale that have been referred to <i>Stenopterygius</i> and <i>Hauffiopteryx</i>, finding four discreet groups, including neonates through adults. She affirms synonymy of several specimens into four species: <i>tricissus</i>, <i>quadricissus</i> and <i>uniter</i>, in <i>Stenopterygius</i>, and <i>typicus</i> in <i>Hauffiopteryx</i>. I wonder why papers that assess quanitiative measures against systematic results receive less attention than systematic results alone, but oh well.
<b>Maxwell, E. E. 2012.</b> New metrics to differentiate species of <i>Stenopterygius</i> (Reptilia: Ichthyosauria) from the Lower Jurassic of southwestern Germany. <i>Journal of Paleontology</i> 86(1):105-115.
item.content:encoded:
Maxwell (2012) uses morphometric (although not geometric) analyses to quantify variation among a variety of elements (skull, vertebrae, appendicular elements) in a broad selection of specimens from the Posidonia Shale that have been referred to Stenopterygius and Hauffiopteryx, finding four discreet groups, including neonates through adults. She affirms synonymy of several specimens into four species: tricissus, quadricissus and uniter, in Stenopterygius, and typicus in Hauffiopteryx. I wonder why papers that assess quanitiative measures against systematic results receive less attention than systematic results alone, but oh well.

Maxwell, E. E. 2012. New metrics to differentiate species of Stenopterygius (Reptilia: Ichthyosauria) from the Lower Jurassic of southwestern Germany. Journal of Paleontology 86(1):105-115.

item.title: By: Mike Keesey (@tmkeesey)
item.dc:creator: Mike Keesey (@tmkeesey)
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/what-is-a-fossil-species/#comment-171">Thomas R. Holtz, Jr.</a>.
I like that. So, what is and isn't a species is dependent on the point in time. Meaning that species are useful in [neontological] ecology (and conservation efforts) but virtually useless in paleontology.
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Thomas R. Holtz, Jr..

I like that. So, what is and isn’t a species is dependent on the point in time. Meaning that species are useful in [neontological] ecology (and conservation efforts) but virtually useless in paleontology.

item.title: By: Thomas R. Holtz, Jr.
item.dc:creator: Thomas R. Holtz, Jr.
item.description:
Absolutely agree about this sudden burst of "fill-in-blank-here level of taxa" studies in recent years: like a flashback to the 1970s and '80s!
Over the last few years I've actually become very partial to Darwin's (often forgotten) species concept: that species were no more or less than well-differentiated varieties distinguished only by the extinction of the gradations intermediate with their closest relatives. (The oft-repeated trope that "Darwin didn't talk about the origin of species in the <i>Origin of Species</i>" is hogwash; what people really mean is "Darwin didn't talk about the origin of Mayrian species in the <i>Origin</i>".
item.content:encoded:
Absolutely agree about this sudden burst of “fill-in-blank-here level of taxa” studies in recent years: like a flashback to the 1970s and ’80s!

Over the last few years I’ve actually become very partial to Darwin’s (often forgotten) species concept: that species were no more or less than well-differentiated varieties distinguished only by the extinction of the gradations intermediate with their closest relatives. (The oft-repeated trope that “Darwin didn’t talk about the origin of species in the Origin of Species” is hogwash; what people really mean is “Darwin didn’t talk about the origin of Mayrian species in the Origin“.

item.title: By: protohedgehog
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/what-is-a-fossil-species/#comment-169">James Lamsdell</a>.
Glad you said that! I hated all these 'high-impact' articles of the last few months talking about a 'burst of family-level diversity' or whatever nonsense..
How is a species a real biological unit though? I mean, you've done loads wrt eurypterids right? How do you rigorously diagnose one species from another..?
Cheers for the book tip! Any chance you know a link where there's a free pdf..? *empty wallet*
item.content:encoded:
In reply to James Lamsdell.

Glad you said that! I hated all these ‘high-impact’ articles of the last few months talking about a ‘burst of family-level diversity’ or whatever nonsense..

How is a species a real biological unit though? I mean, you’ve done loads wrt eurypterids right? How do you rigorously diagnose one species from another..?

Cheers for the book tip! Any chance you know a link where there’s a free pdf..? *empty wallet*

item.title: By: James Lamsdell
item.dc:creator: James Lamsdell
item.description: Higher taxonomic ranks are never comparable between different groups and therefore don't exist; the only real biological unit is the species. Grab a copy of the Wiley and Lieberman phylogenetics books for a breakdown on the current thought on this sort of thing.
item.content:encoded: Higher taxonomic ranks are never comparable between different groups and therefore don’t exist; the only real biological unit is the species. Grab a copy of the Wiley and Lieberman phylogenetics books for a breakdown on the current thought on this sort of thing.
